metadata.title: Natural Halloysite Nano-Clay Electrolyte for Advanced All-Solid-State Lithium-Sulfur Batteries

sections.text:
Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) show increasing potential for application in high energy lithium sulfur batteries due to good flexibility and high safety. However, low room temperature ionic conductivity of SPEs has become the main limitation. Herein, a novel SPE film using natural halloysite nano-clay has been fabricated, which exhibits exceptional ionic conductivity of 1.11×10-4 S cm-1 and lithium ion transference number of 0.40 at 25 oC. The mechanism of enhanced lithium ion transport is considered. The oppositely charged halloysite nanotube surfaces separate lithium salt into lithium ions that are absorbed on the negatively charged outer tube silica surface, and anions may be accommodated on the positively charged inner tube aluminol surface. So, an ordered 3D structure for free lithium ion transport is suggested. This potential application of the natural halloysite nano-clay has been demonstrated by an all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery over a wide temperature range of 25-100 oC. These results reveal the possibility of realizing
sustainable high energy storage at a reduced cost.
Keywords: Halloysite nanotube; Nano-clay; Solid polymer electrolyte; Flexible film; Lithium-sulfur battery

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Development of electric vehicles and portable electronic devices has led to a strong demand for high energy storage systems [1, 2]. Compared to conventional lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries have a higher theoretical capacity of 1672 mAh g-1, higher energy density of 2600 Wh kg-1 and are considered to be the next-generation advanced lithium batteries [3, 4]. However, this kind of battery is facing serious challenges, especially regarding the length of the cycle life, narrow range of operating temperature, and high cost. In order to solve these problems, previous research has mainly focused on modification of electrode materials [5-8], while fewer efforts have considered the electrolyte, although a crucial part in a battery.
The electrolyte provides lithium ions, a pathway for ion transport, and insulation
to prevent electron transfer between cathode and anode [9, 10]. Ionic conductivity of the electrolyte significantly affects battery performance. Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) not only have better flexibility and mechanical properties than solid inorganic electrolytes, but also have better safety characteristics than liquid organic electrolytes [10-12]. However, low room temperature ionic conductivity may restrict SPE application in batteries. Various modifications have been reported
[13-15]. Experimental research has found that ionic conductivity can be increased to 10-5 S cm-1 from 10-7 S cm-1 at room temperature by the addition of nano-materials to the SPEs [13, 16-19], for example, 10 wt% SiO2 nanoparticles in a PEO electrolyte [17]. An all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery assembled with the electrolyte exhibited about 800 mAh g−1 capacity after 25 cycles at 70 oC [20]. Recently, MIL53(Al), a kind of metal-organic framework of nanoparticles with diamond-shaped channels, was used to prepare a PEO based electrolyte for which an ionic conductivity of 1.62×10-5 S cm-1 at 30 oC was measured [18]. By using the electrolyte, the all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery achieved an initial discharge capacity of 1520 mAh g-1, and approximately reached the theoretical capacity. Even after 1000 cycles at 80 oC and 4 C (1 C = 1672 mA g-1), 325 mAh g-1 remained [21]. In addition to nano-fillers it has been reported that by growing one-dimensional carbon nanotubes (CNTs) within montmorillonite clay an ionic conductivity of 2.07 × 10-5 S cm-1 can be attained at 25 oC [19]. These results indicate that nano materials with an ordered structure may be a fascinating approach to increase the ionic conductivity of PEO based SPEs.
In nature, numerous nano-resources possess 1D, 2D, or 3D ordered structures. Of particular interest is the halloysite nanotube (HNT). Halloysite is a aluminosilicate (Al2Si2O5(OH)4) natural nano-clay with a tubular 3D structure having oppositely charged surfaces [22]. Due to the special surface properties, eco-friendly preparation and low cost, HNT has been used as a multifunctional material in polymers and plastic, electronic components, drug delivery, cosmetics and personal care products [23-25].
Recent studies show that HNT can be used to improve the lithium ionic conductivity for gel electrolytes [26], and proton conductivity for proton-exchange membranes [27]. In this study, we demonstrate and develop, for the first time, the use of HNT in a flexible solid electrolyte film for all-solid-state lithium-sulfur batteries. The ionic conductivity for the HNT solid polymer electrolyte of 1.11×10-4 S cm-1 at 25 oC, and 2.14×10-3 S cm-1 at 100 oC is comparable to the latest reported starch based SPE [14]. Using the HNT nanocomposite electrolyte, the all-solid-state lithium-sulfur batteries can operate at a wide temperature range of 25-100 oC. Mechanisms of lithium ion conduction are investigated by electrochemical methods, surface charge measurements, infrared spectrometry and optical microscopy. The results demonstrate a great potential for the use of natural clay minerals in new energy materials and devices.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preparation and characterization of flexible SPE
sections.text:
Polyethylene oxide (PEO, MW=4×10 6, Xiamen TOB New Energy Technology Company), lithium bis(triuoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, 99.5%, Acros) and halloysite nanotubes (HNT, 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich) were dried before use. HNT, LiTFSI and PEO were mixed in acetonitrile (CH3CN, AR grade) to form a homogenized solution. The solution was cast and dried into a thin film in an argon filled glove box at 60 oC, and a PEO+LiTFSI+HNT electrolyte thin film was made.
The electrochemical properties of the electrolyte were measured using a Gamry
electrochemical instrument. The ionic conductivities of the electrolyte films were evaluated by the complex plane impedance plots between 25 oC and 100 oC with an impedance analyzer. Each film was sandwiched between a stainless steel (SS) disc (d = 1.6 cm) and the positive shell of a 2025 coin cell to form a symmetric SS/electrolyte/SS cell. The equation for calculating the conductivity is
where l is the thickness of the electrolyte, Rb is the resistance of the electrolyte and the intercept of the x-axis of the straight line, and S is the area of the blocking stainless steel electrodes.
The Li+ ion transference number (t+) of the electrolyte film was tested in a
symmetric cell (Li/PEO+LiTFSI+HNT/Li). When a constant polarization voltage of 10 mV was applied to the cell, a current was measured from the initial value to a steady-state value after 4 hours. AC impedance plots of the film before and after polarization were obtained. The frequency range was from 300 KHz to 10 Hz and the signal amplitude was 10 mV. The t+ is given by the following expression:
where V is the DC voltage applied to the cell; R0 and Rs are the initial and steady-state resistances of the passivating layer, respectively; and I0 and Is are the initial and steady-state current, respectively.
Electrochemical stability of the electrolyte film was measured by linear sweep voltammetry using Li/PEO+LiTFSI+HNT/SS cells at a scan rate of 10 mV S-1 and range
bSR

)RI(VI
)RI(VI t
ss0

of 3-8 V. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted by SDT Q600 to investigate thermal stability of the electrolytes and HNT. The samples were tested in an argon atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 oC min-1. The mechanical stability of the thin film electrolyte was measured with a dynamometer. The electrolyte films were fixed on a base and automatically pulled by the dynamometer connected to a lifting device. They were made into long strips with width of 15 mm, thickness of about 0.13 mm, and initial stretch length of 30 mm. The morphology of the electrolyte film was investigated by optical microscopy.
Zeta potential and surface charge characteristics of the HNT nanoparticle samples in LiTFSI acetonitrile solution were measured using a Brookhaven ZetaPALS instrument. The HNT concentration in the suspension was fixed in 0.5 mg mL-1 and the LiTFSI/HNT weight ratio varied from 0 to 8. For the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) measurements, the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT, PEO+LiTFSI, PEO, LiTFSI and HNT samples were made in acetonitrile solution, coated on a Ge plate, followed by evaporation of the solvent. The spectra were collected with a BIO-RAD FTS 6000 SPECTROMETER.

sections.heading: 2.2 Battery test
sections.text:
The PEO+LiTFSI+HNT or PEO+LiTFSI based lithium-sulfur battery was assembled by contacting in sequence a lithium metal disk anode (d = 15.6 mm, thickness = 0.3 mm), the electrolyte film, and a disk of macro-structural sulfur cathode (d = 10 mm). The sulfur cathode was fabricated as previously reported with a sulfur content of about 30.1% [21]. The electrode-electrolyte was housed and sealed in a 2025 coin cell to
build a Li/PEO+LiTFSI+HNT/sulfur battery. All batteries were assembled in an argon filled glove box. Galvanostatic charge/discharge cycling was performed in a LAND CT2001A battery test system. Cyclic voltammograms of the battery at 25 oC and 100 oC were carried out at voltage range of 3.0-1.2 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s-1 and 3.0-1.5 V at a scan rate of 0.5 mV s-1, respectively. The cut-off voltage of the discharge and charge process was respectively 1.2 and 3.0 V at 25 oC, 1.5 and 3.0 V at 100 oC. Rate performance of the lithium-sulfur batteries with PEO+LiTFSI+HNT or PEO+LiTFSI electrolyte at 100 oC were evaluated by cycling the batteries at 0.3 C for the first 4 cycles, 2 C for 10 cycles, 4 C for 10 cycles, back to 2 C for 10 cycles and finally back to 0.3 C for 5 cycles. The impedances of the batteries before and after cycling were measured.

sections.heading: 3.1 Lithium ionic conductivity of electrolyte
sections.text:
Ionic conductivity is a crucial parameter to determine the Li+ ion transport capability of an electrolyte. In order to obtain high ionic conductivity, the composition of the electrolyte was optimized by adjusting the weight ratio of the halloysite nanotube (HNT)/polyethylene oxide (PEO) and molar ratio of ethylene oxide (EO) in PEO and Li in LiTFSI, which results can be seen in Fig. 1a and Fig. 1b.
Previous studies found that the ionic conductivity of the PEO based electrolyte is
higher in the amorphous state than in the crystalline state [28, 29]. A decrease of the crystalline transition temperature will increase the ionic conductivity. Thus, the
measurement of the phase transition temperature is essential. The experimental data in Fig. 1a and Fig. 1b are fitted by the Arrhenius equation at low temperature (linear, crystalline phase) and by the Vogel-Tamman-Fulcher (VTF) equation at high temperature (non-linear curve, amorphous phase) [30]. So, the phase transition temperatures can be measured at the crossing point of the two fitted lines, which are 56.9, 48.7, 42.3, 42.1 and 42.3 oC, respectively for HNT concentrations of 0, 5, 10, 15 and 17% by weight when EO:Li is 15:1 (see inset of Fig. 1a). The electrolyte with 10% HNT has the highest ionic conductivity at the temperature range. Hence the HNT concentration of 10% was fixed for further examination of the EO:Li ratio. The phase transition temperature was found to be 62.6, 47.2 and 42.3 oC for EO:Li of 25:1, 20:1 and 15:1. For EO:Li ratios of 10:1 and 8:1, the curves become smooth and no such inflection points for phase transition were found, indicating that a homogeneous and amorphous phase exists. However, the ionic conductivity at EO:Li = 15:1 is obviously higher than at EO:Li = 8:1.
As the temperature increases, the ionic conductivity of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT
electrolyte increases more steadily than PEO+LiTFSI. The highest ionic conductivity was attained with the presence of 10% HNT and an EO:Li molar ratio of 15:1. Typical impedance spectra of PEO+LiTFSI(EO:Li=15:1)+HNT(10%) for the ionic conductivity calculation at selected temperatures of 25, 35, 45, 55, 65, 80 and 100 oC are shown in the inset of Fig. 1b. The ionic conductivity data are listed in the inset of Fig. 1c. At 25, 60 and 100 oC, the highest ionic conductivities are 1.11×10-4, 1.34×10-3 and 2.14×10-3 S cm-1, respectively. Generally, the room temperature ionic conductivity of polymer
based solid electrolytes ranges from 10-8 to 10-4 S cm-1 [9, 11, 31-34]; thus, this HNT solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) shows distinctive ionic conductibility. The optimal conditions were maintained in the following measurements.
Figure 1 Lithium ion transport for HNT nanocomposite electrolytes. (a) Ionic conductivities of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT films with different HNT contents at EO:Li=15:1 as a function of temperature, inset is the phase transition temperature as HNT content obtained after fitting. (b) Ionic conductivities of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT with different EO:Li ratios(▲25:1; ★20:1; ●15:1; 10:1; ▼8:1) at the HNT content of 10% as a function of temperature, inset shows the impedance spectra of PEO+LiTFSI(EO:Li=15:1)+HNT(10%) at selected temperatures. (c) Optical photos of PEO, PEO+LiTFSI, PEO+LiTFSI(EO:Li=15:1)+HNT(10%) at a magnification of 50 and ionic conductivity table of PEO+LiTFSI, PEO+LiTFSI(EO:Li=15:1)+HNT(10%) at 25, 60 and 100 oC. (d) Room temperature chronoamperometry of the Li/PEO+LiTFSI+HNT/Li cell at a potential step of 10 mV. Inset: the AC impedance spectra of the same cell before polarization and after steady-state current conditions.
In order to further investigate the relationship between the ionic conductivity
and the amorphous phase, an optical microscope at a magnification of 50 was used
to directly observe the crystallization behavior, and the optical images of pure PEO, PEO+LiTFSI, PEO+LiTFSI (EO:Li=15:1)+HNT (10%) are shown in Fig. 1c. The crystal size in PEO+LiTFSI is reduced after adding LiTFSI. With the addition of HNT to PEO+LiTFSI, the size is further reduced. Hence, the decreases both in the phase transition temperature and the crystal size are suggested to explain the increase of ionic conductivity.
In addition to the high room temperature ionic conductivity, the HNT
nanocomposite electrolyte also provides a higher lithium ion transference number (t+), as shown in Fig. 1d. The t+ was measured by using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy combined with a potential polarization. At the beginning of the polarization, both Li+ cations and anions move and contribute to the current. While at the steady state, only Li+ ion transports from one electrode to the other [35]. The value measured for the HNT nanocomposite electrolyte is 0.40, which is 4 times higher than that of pure PEO (0.1 measured with the same method; the value for the pure PEO electrolyte is usually in the range of 0.1-0.25 [17, 18]) electrolyte at room temperature. The high Li+ ionic conductivity is indeed assigned to the HNT contribution.

sections.heading: 3.2 Electrochemical, thermal and mechanical stability of electrolyte
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows linear sweep voltammetry, thermal analysis and the stress-strain characteristics of the solid polymer electrolytes to evaluate the electrochemical, thermal and mechanical stability, respectively. In Fig. 2a, it is found that the HNT based SPE is stable up to 6.35 and 4.78 V respectively at 25 and 100 oC, both of which
are higher than the decomposition voltage of commercial liquid organic electrolytes (~4.2 V). As a comparison, the steady voltage of PEO+LiTFSI is 4.52 V at 100 oC. The electrochemical stability is greatly enhanced by adding HNT.
Figure 2 Electrochemical, thermal and mechanical stability of the HNT nanocomposite electrolyte. (a) Linear sweep voltammetry Li/PEO+LiTFSI+HNT/SS cells at 25 oC and 100 oC, and SS/PEO+LiTFSI/Li cells at 100 oC at a rate of 10 mV s-1. (b) Thermogravimetric analysis of PEO+LiTFSI+HNT, PEO+LiTFSI and HNT. (c) Stress-strain curves of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT and PEO+LiTFSI electrolytes. (d) Photos of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT film at initial and final tension state.
In Fig. 2b, thermal degradations are observed in the temperature range of
50-800 oC for PEO+LiTFSI+HNT, PEO+LiTFSI electrolytes and HNT. Below 380 oC, the curves of the three samples overlap with weight loss of about 2.0%. The weight loss below 105 oC of about 0.8% is due to the water absorbed from the atmosphere. From 105 to 380 oC, 1.2% weight loss may be due to the loss of structural water. The main degradation of the electrolytes from about 380 to 450 oC corresponds to the decomposition of PEO and LiTFSI [36]. The residuals for the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT and
PEO+LiTFSI electrolytes are respectively 12% and 6%, which difference of 6% is due to the HNT thermal stability. Besides, it can be seen that HNT is stable up to about 430 oC with a weight loss of 12%. The residual of 86% above 500 oC may be from Al2O3 and SiO2 nanoparticles. Thus, with the addition of HNT the SPE still displays strong thermal stability.
In order to characterize the mechanical strength of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT and
PEO+LiTFSI electrolytes tensile strength tests were performed by using a homemade set up. The electrolyte films were fixed on a heavy base and automatically pulled by a dynamometer connected to a lifting device. The stress as strain changes was recorded and the data fitted by the equation y=ab/(1+bx) (y is stress, x is strain, a and b are the constants), as shown in Fig. 2c. The photos of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT film at the initial and final tension states can be seen in Fig. 2d. The stress for both electrolytes increases linearly with strain and finally reaches steady value. Even after stretch in 400% strain state, the electrolytes remain non-fractured, demonstrating good flexibility of the SPEs. However, the stress of the HNT electrolyte is higher than the pure PEO electrolyte in the whole stretching process. The stress of 2.28 MPa for the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT electrolyte at strain of 400% is obviously bigger than 1.25 MPa for the PEO+LiTFSI electrolyte. This enhancement in the mechanical strength can be absolutely attributed to the addition of HNT.

sections.heading: 3.3 The effect of HNT on lithium ion conductivity
sections.text:
The halloysite nanotube (HNT) is a layered aluminosilicate, Al2Si2O5(OH)4, with a
naturally occurring tubular structure at a nanoscale [22]. HNTs have typical
dimensions of 10-50 nm for the outer diameter and 5-20 nm for the inner diameter, with a length for 50 to 1000 nm [37]. The nanotube materials have two face surfaces; the outer surface contains a -Si-O-Si- silica tetrahedral sheet, while the inner surface consists of -Al-OH groups from the octahedral sheet. Our previous studies on kaolinite (same composition as halloysite, but flat plate nanoparticles rather than tubes) showed that the inner aluminol face surface is positively charged, whereas the silica face surface is negatively charged [38, 39]. This distinction in surfaces enables selective immobilization of charged species, such that negatively charged species will have an additional driving force for adsorption inside the tube while positively charged species will be accommodated on the outside of the nanotube [37, 40].
Figure 3 Preparation of HNT modified flexible electrolyte and mechanism of HNT addition for enhanced ionic conductivity. The halloysite nanotube, LiTFSI and PEO are mixed in the solvent to form a uniform electrolyte solution. The solution is cast in an argon atmosphere to produce a flexible electrolyte thin film.
For the HNT based SPEs, HNT, LiTFSI and PEO are mixed uniformly in the solvent.
See Fig. 3 which shows preparation and describes enhanced lithium ion conductivity. The opposite surface charge on the HNT faces will separate lithium salt into lithium
ions that are absorbed on the outer negatively charged silica surface, and (NSO2CF3)2 - anions that are expected to be adsorbed at the inner, positively charged aluminol surface. However, the EO units on PEO also have an abundance of lone-pair electrons that will interact with the Li+ ions on the outer HNT surface, as the polymer becomes organized and conformed to the HNT nanoparticles. The Lewis acid-base interactions among HNT, LiTFSI, and PEO effectively order the ions into the 3D channels. These interactions will significantly shorten the distance of free Li+ ion transfer, lower ionic coupling, disturb the PEO crystallinity, decrease the phase transition temperature, and provide a high-speed freeway for lithium ion transport. They also make the SPE thin film electrolyte more uniform with better mechanical strength.
Zeta potential measurements and FTIR characterization were carried out to
further investigate the proposed mechanism. Suspensions with different weight ratios of LiTFSI/HNT in acetonitrile were prepared for the measurements of zeta potential, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. At a ratio of 0, the zeta potential is -70.39 mV. As the ratio increases, the zeta potential increases from negative to positive with a reversal in the sign of the zeta potential at a ratio of 4. This ratio is close to the LiTFSI/HNT ratio with the highest ionic conductivity in the electrolyte. Thus, the charge reversal of the HNT particles reveals the change in adsorption of Li+ ions at the HNT surface.
Figure 4 Zeta potential of HNT nanoparticle samples as weight ratio of LiTFSI/HNT in acetonitrile suspension.
In addition, Fig. 5a shows the complete FTIR spectra of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT,
PEO+LiTFSI, PEO, LiTFSI and HNT for the 4000-300 cm-1 region and Fig. 5b presents the detailed spectra for the 1400-1150 cm-1 region. In the spectrum of PEO+LiTFSI+HNT of Fig. 5b, the peaks at 1186 and 1205 cm-1 shift respectively to 1182 and 1210 cm-1 compared with PEO+LiTFSI. Compared with neat PEO, LiTFSI and HNT, new peaks at 1229 and 1186 cm-1 emerge in the spectrum of PEO+LiTFSI and the peak at 1327 cm-1 shifts to 1335 cm-1. The peaks and corresponding assignments for PEO+LiTFSI+HNT, PEO+LiTFSI, PEO and LiTFSI are listed in Table 1.
Table 1 FTIR peaks and assignments for PEO+LiTFSI+HNT, PEO+LiTFSI, PEO and LiTFSI Peak assignment Wavenumber / cm-1

Weight ratio of LiTFSI/HNT
According to the peak assignments of PEO, LiTFSI and HNT, the new peaks in
PEO+LiTFSI can be assigned to the splits of symmetric and asymmetric stretching of -CF3. The upward shift of -SO2- and splits of -CF3 stretching demonstrate that the dissociation of LiTFSI by the solid “solvent” PEO occurs [43, 44]. It is noticed that obvious shifts of -CF3 absorption occur when HNT is added to form PEO+LiTFSI+HNT electrolyte, while the peak locations of -CH2- for PEO and -SO2- remain almost the same. These results reveal that an interaction of HNT with -CF3 of the (NSO2CF3)2 - anion exists. In this way the dissociation of lithium salt is enhanced and special lithium ion transport may be provided.
Figure 5 FTIR spectra of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT, PEO+LiTFSI, PEO, LiTFSI and HNT at (a) 4000-300 cm-1 and (b) 1400-1150 cm-1.

sections.heading: 3.4 All-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery performance
sections.text:
The 10% HNT and EO:Li=15:1 SPE films were used to fabricate high capacity all-solid-state lithium-sulfur batteries, the electrochemical performance of which shown in Fig. 6. The sulfur cathode was synthesized as in our previous work [21], in which the battery delivered the initial discharge capacity near the theoretical value
and showed a stable cycling life. The assembly of the battery is shown in Fig. 6a. The sulfur cathode on aluminum foil, HNT nanocomposite electrolyte, and lithium anode were stacked in sequence and hydraulically pressed using CR2025 shells.
Figure 6 All-solid-state lithium-sulfur coin battery performance. (a) Structure of the all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery. (b) Discharge/charge curves of the all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery at 25 oC and 0.1 C. (c) Cyclic voltammograms of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT based all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery in the voltage range of 3.0-1.2 V at 25 oC and a scan rate of 0.1 mV s-1. (d) Cycling performance of the battery at 25 oC and 0.1 C. (e) Cyclic voltammograms of the battery in the voltage range of 3.0-1.5 V at 100 oC and a scan rate of 0.5 mV s-1. (f) Cycling performance of the battery at 100 oC, 0.3 C for the first 2 cycles and 4 C for the following 398 cycles.
Fig. 6b are the discharge/charge profiles of the all-solid-state lithium-sulfur
battery at 25 oC and 0.1 C (1 C = 1672 mA g-1). In the first discharge cycle, two plateaus at 2.4-2.3 V and 2.0-1.5 V are seen. The total initial discharge capacity is 1350 mAh g-1. During the first charging process, only one plateau at 2.1-2.5 V is present, and the initial charge capacity is 747 mAh g-1. In the second discharge process, the plateau at 2.4-2.3 V disappears and a sloped curve at 2.2-1.5 V appears with a capacity of 854 mAh g-1. The capacity holds in the following cycles.
Fig. 6c presents the CV curves for the battery at 25 oC. In the first reduction scan,
there exist two remarkable peaks at 1.85 V and 2.36 V, but in the first oxidation scan, only one peak at approximately 2.38 V is observed. In the following cycles, the position of the oxidation peak does not change, while the reduction peak at 2.36 V disappears and the reduction peak at 1.85 V moves to a little bit higher position, revealing a reduced polarization after the first cycle. In addition, the CV curves of the third and fourth cycles are basically overlapped. This behavior is in agreement with the performance of the battery using the same cathode but a MIL-53 modified PEO electrolyte at 80 oC [21]. The operating temperature of the batteries is lowered by 55 oC with the HNT solid electrolyte. The CV results are in agreement with the charge/discharge behavior in Fig. 6b.
In the meantime, the corresponding cycling performance of the battery at 25 oC
and 0.1 C is displayed in Fig. 6d. The battery presents stable discharge capacities with an averaged value of 745 ± 21 mAh g-1 in the 100 discharge/charge cycles, with 87% retention compared to the second discharge capacity, and close to 100% efficiency for each cycle is achieved.
The first reduction in CV and discharge curve during the 1st cycle is related to the
transformation of macro-structural sulfur to -S4 2-, and the second process is associated with reduction of -S4 2- to -S2-. Only one oxidation process indicates that -S2- is oxidized to -S4 2- instead of macro-structural -S8. This change of macro-structural -S8 to -S4 2- causes the capacity decrease in the first cycle. But the intermediate is electrochemically stable and the battery shows high efficiency with close to 100% for all other cycles.
High temperature CV data for the battery were also measured at 100 oC (Fig. 6e).
The shape of the curves is similar to those at 25 oC, but the reduction peak (~1.85 V) moves to higher levels (~2.05 V) and the oxidation peak (~2.38 V) to lower levels (~2.25 V). This implies a decrease in polarization, revealing higher ionic conductivity of the electrolyte and better surface contact between the electrolyte and electrodes at high temperature.
The cycling performance of the battery at 100 oC is presented in Fig. 6f. At 0.3 C, the initial discharge capacity is 1493 mAh g-1, which is reduced to 910 mAh g-1 for the 2nd cycle. In order to further test a faster charge/discharge ability of the battery, experiments with an increase in the current rate of 4 C were performed. The battery delivers the discharge capacity of 809 mAh g-1. After 400 cycles, the battery still has a discharge capacity of 386 mAh g-1 and close to 100% efficiency for each cycle. These cycling results demonstrate that the natural halloysite nano-clay electrolyte for all-solid-state lithium-sulfur batteries can provide outstanding performance over a wide temperature range of 25-100 oC.
Rate performance of the lithium-sulfur battery with PEO+LiTFSI+HNT electrolyte was compared with the battery having PEO+LiTFSI electrolyte at 100 oC and the results are shown in Fig. 7a. At all rates, the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT based battery shows higher capacity than that without HNT. The first discharge capacity for the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT based battery is 1410 mAh g-1 and the average discharge capacities for the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT based battery are 919, 692, 545, 647 and 805 mAh g-1 respectively for rates of 0.3, 2, 4, 2 and 0.3 C. However, the initial discharge capacity of the PEO+LiTFSI based battery is 1333 mAh g-1, and the average discharge capacities for the PEO+LiTFSI based battery are 798, 534, 409, 478 and 630 mAh g-1 respectively at the same rates that show an average decrease of 152 mAh g-1. These indicate that the battery with HNT has significantly high capacity and cycling performance.
Figure 7 Rate performance of PEO+LiTFSI+HNT (green) and PEO+LiTFSI (purple) electrolyte based lithium-sulfur batteries at 100 oC. (a) Capacity at 0.3, 2, 4, 2 and 0.3 C. (b) EIS spectra of both the batteries before (solid) and after cycles (hollow).
In order to understand the better rate performance of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT based battery, the impedance spectra of the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT and PEO+LiTFSI based batteries before and after 39 charge-discharge cycles were measured and the results
are present in Fig.7b. The high-frequency intercept on the real axis represents the ohmic resistance (Ro) of the cell, including the electrolyte and electrode resistances. The diameter of the semi-circle in the high frequency region gives the charge-transfer resistance Rct at the electrodes/electrolyte interface. All the spectra show the same shape with one semi-circle at high frequency and an inclined line in the low frequency region. Therefore, no new interface is formed after cycles, demonstrating good stability of the electrolyte with both electrodes. The values of Ro and Rct for the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT battery are 13.4 and 461.6 Ω (before cycling), and 13.6 and 510.8 Ω (after cycling), while the corresponding values for the PEO+LiTFSI battery are 23.4 and 837 Ω (before cycling), and 24.0 and 1290 Ω (after cycling). The Ro value for the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT based battery is lower, which is due to the higher ionic conductivity. However, for each battery, the Ro after cycling remains almost the same as before cycling, indicating good ionic conductivity for both electrolytes. The PEO+LiTFSI+HNT electrolyte has a lower Rct before cycling compared with PEO+LiTFSI. In addition, the PEO+LiTFSI+HNT electrolyte also shows a smaller increase of 11% in Rct after cycling than that of 54% for the PEO+LiTFSI electrolyte. The lower and more stable Rct appears to be the reason for higher capacity.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this work, natural halloysite nanotubes were directly used as solid electrolyte filler. Due to the oppositely charged surface of HNT, the dissociation of lithium salt is promoted by the ordered 3D channels in the electrolyte. Thus, the lithium ionic conductivity is greatly increased. The interactions have proved to enhance both
electrochemical and mechanical stability of the electrolyte. The relation between the halloysite nanotube and the arrangement of cation, anion and PEO are being investigated to further improve the electrolyte performance. With the low cost electrolyte, the all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery can be cycled with high capacity and long life at 25-100 oC. The results with the natural HNT clay mineral demonstrate an efficient way to realize a wide temperature range for this high energy battery system at low cost with high safety and ecofriendly use.

Yue Lin is currently a Ph.D. student under the supervision of Professor Jin Liu at Central South University and visiting student
under the supervision of Professor Jan D. Miller and Research Professor Xuming Wang at the University of Utah. She received her Bachelor's degree in Metallurgical Engineering in 2011 and Master’s degree of Non-ferrous Metallurgy in 2014 from Central South University, China. Her research interests include synthesis of new energy materials for all-solid-state energy storage systems.
Xuming Wang is a research professor in the Department of Metallurgical Engineering, University of Utah, USA, where he received his Ph.D. degree in Metallurgical Engineering in 2004. His research interests include mineral processing, surface chemistry, mineral utilization in advanced materials, such as his recent research in battery materials. Recently Dr. Wang was recognized by the Institution of Civil Engineers with the 2016 Best Paper
Award for a paper published in Surface Innovations.
Jin Liu is a professor in the School of Metallurgy and Environment, Central South University, China. She received her Ph.D. degree from the Department of Chemistry, University of Utah, USA in 2006. Her research interests include electrochemistry and surface chemistry.
Jan D. Miller has served on the Metallurgical Engineering Faculty at the University of Utah for almost 50 years where he is the Ivor D. Thomas Distinguished Professor. He received his engineering degrees from the Pennsylvania State University and the Colorado School of Mines. A member of the National Academy of Engineering, his research interests include surface chemistry and particle characterization especially with respect to mineral

metadata.abstractText: Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) show increasing potential for application in high energy lithium sulfur batteries due to good flexibility and high safety. However, low room temperature ionic conductivity of SPEs has become the main limitation. Herein, a novel SPE film using natural halloysite nano-clay has been fabricated, which exhibits exceptional ionic conductivity of 1.11×10 S cm and lithium ion transference number of 0.40 at 25 C. The mechanism of enhanced lithium ion transport is considered. The oppositely charged halloysite nanotube surfaces separate lithium salt into lithium ions that are absorbed on the negatively charged outer tube silica surface, and anions may be accommodated on the positively charged inner tube aluminol surface. So, an ordered 3D structure for free lithium ion transport is suggested. This potential application of the natural halloysite nano-clay has been demonstrated by an all-solid-state lithium-sulfur battery over a wide temperature range of 25-100 C. These results reveal the possibility of realizing
metadata.creator: Elsevier
